messages.subject: Re: Heianjo Sukashi questions
messages.msgSnippet: I never meant to elevate Sotheby s in general to the pantheon of authority, but Bob Hyanes was did provide special assistance on this sale.  That was the
messages.messageBody:
I never meant to elevate Sotheby's in general to the pantheon of
authority, but Bob Hyanes was did provide "special assistance" on
this sale. That was the main reason I cited it. It's just a
curious variance in terminiology as far as I can tell.
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@s...>
wrote:
> My explanation was based on Japanese sources and Japanese usage.
Wakayama
> sensei in particular did not like the use of Heianjo sukashi. I
would hope
> that Sothebys is not got the final say on how tsuba are described.
>
> Gordon
>
> -----Original Message-----

[mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On

> Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Heianjo Sukashi questions
>
> Based on my own meager knowledge, I would agree with Gordon but
the
> new Sotheby's catalog lists a tsuba that looks very Kyo to me as
> Heianjo. (lot no 722) It then goes on to list a few pages of Kyo
> tsuba. It would seem that by their working definition that
Curran's
> explanation of Ko-Kyo might be correct given that the Heianjo is
> early-mid 15th C while the others are more than a century later.
>
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Robson <robsongo@s...>
> wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> > The old term Heianjo Sukashi is no longer in use having been
> replaced

this
> > term. This also helps avoid confusion with Heianjo tsuba, which
> are
> > typically thin iron plates with brass inlays.
> >
> > Gordon

> >
> > > I think I asked this same question of Jim or somebody
> > > else not long ago. It confused me a bit regarding a
> > > tsuba I was studying at the time.
> > >
> > > My understanding is that it is more of an age
> > > division. For example, exact same Sasano tsuba is
> > > photographed in 2 books. It is a mid 1500s piece. In
> > > the older book it is called 'Heian Jo Sukashi'. In
> > > another book it is called 'Kyo Sukashi' and the age is
> > > denoted in the subsequent description.
> > > I suppose you could call it a "ko kyo" sukashi, but
> > > sounds odd to me.
> > >
> > > I would have thought Richard George's first tsuba

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Heianjo Sukashi questions
messages.msgSnippet: My explanation was based on Japanese sources and Japanese usage. Wakayama sensei in particular did not like the use of Heianjo sukashi. I would hope that
messages.messageBody:
My explanation was based on Japanese sources and Japanese usage. Wakayama
sensei in particular did not like the use of Heianjo sukashi. I would hope
that Sothebys is not got the final say on how tsuba are described.

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of frkirk
Sent: Monday, July 11, 2005 10:08 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Heianjo Sukashi questions

Based on my own meager knowledge, I would agree with Gordon but the
new Sotheby's catalog lists a tsuba that looks very Kyo to me as
Heianjo. (lot no 722) It then goes on to list a few pages of Kyo
tsuba. It would seem that by their working definition that Curran's
explanation of Ko-Kyo might be correct given that the Heianjo is
early-mid 15th C while the others are more than a century later.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Robson <robsongo@s...>
wrote:
> Hi,
>
> The old term Heianjo Sukashi is no longer in use having been
replaced
> by Kyo-Sukushi. If you have an older book, you will still see this
> term. This also helps avoid confusion with Heianjo tsuba, which
are
> typically thin iron plates with brass inlays.
>
> Gordon
>
> On 2005/07/11, at 1:54, Curran Campbell wrote:
>
> > I think I asked this same question of Jim or somebody
> > else not long ago. It confused me a bit regarding a
> > tsuba I was studying at the time.
> >
> > My understanding is that it is more of an age
> > division. For example, exact same Sasano tsuba is
> > photographed in 2 books. It is a mid 1500s piece. In
> > the older book it is called 'Heian Jo Sukashi'. In
> > another book it is called 'Kyo Sukashi' and the age is
> > denoted in the subsequent description.
> > I suppose you could call it a "ko kyo" sukashi, but
> > sounds odd to me.
> >
> > I would have thought Richard George's first tsuba
> > could be called "Heianjo Sukashi" or late Muromachi.
> >
> >
> > Curran
> >
> >
> >
> > --- David Zincavage <jdz@i...> wrote:
> >
> >> I'm a bit puzzled about Heianjo sukashi tsubas. Why
> >> do you suppose it is that neither Torigoye nor
> >> Sasano discuss them? Heianjo, in this case, I would
> >> assume, just means they were made in Kyoto. So, how
> >> would Heianjo sukashi be different from Kyo
> >> sukashi? How does one identify these?
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> [Non-text portions of this message have been
> >> removed]
> >>
> >>
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > ____________________________________________________

Based on my own meager knowledge, I would agree with Gordon but the
new Sotheby's catalog lists a tsuba that looks very Kyo to me as
Heianjo. (lot no 722) It then goes on to list a few pages of Kyo
tsuba. It would seem that by their working definition that Curran's
explanation of Ko-Kyo might be correct given that the Heianjo is
early-mid 15th C while the others are more than a century later.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Heianjo Sukashi questions
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, The old term Heianjo Sukashi is no longer in use having been replaced by Kyo-Sukushi. If you have an older book, you will still see this term. This also
messages.messageBody:
Hi,

The old term Heianjo Sukashi is no longer in use having been replaced
by Kyo-Sukushi. If you have an older book, you will still see this
term. This also helps avoid confusion with Heianjo tsuba, which are
typically thin iron plates with brass inlays.

Gordon

On 2005/07/11, at 1:54, Curran Campbell wrote:

> I think I asked this same question of Jim or somebody
> else not long ago. It confused me a bit regarding a
> tsuba I was studying at the time.
>
> My understanding is that it is more of an age
> division. For example, exact same Sasano tsuba is
> photographed in 2 books. It is a mid 1500s piece. In
> the older book it is called 'Heian Jo Sukashi'. In
> another book it is called 'Kyo Sukashi' and the age is
> denoted in the subsequent description.
> I suppose you could call it a "ko kyo" sukashi, but
> sounds odd to me.
>
> I would have thought Richard George's first tsuba
> could be called "Heianjo Sukashi" or late Muromachi.
>
>
> Curran
>
>
>
> --- David Zincavage <jdz@...> wrote:
>
>> I'm a bit puzzled about Heianjo sukashi tsubas. Why
>> do you suppose it is that neither Torigoye nor
>> Sasano discuss them? Heianjo, in this case, I would
>> assume, just means they were made in Kyoto. So, how
>> would Heianjo sukashi be different from Kyo
>> sukashi? How does one identify these?
>>
>>
>>
>> [Non-text portions of this message have been
>> removed]
>>
>>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Heianjo Sukashi questions
messages.msgSnippet: I think I asked this same question of Jim or somebody else not long ago. It confused me a bit regarding a tsuba I was studying at the time. My understanding is
messages.messageBody:
I think I asked this same question of Jim or somebody
else not long ago. It confused me a bit regarding a
tsuba I was studying at the time.

My understanding is that it is more of an age
division. For example, exact same Sasano tsuba is
photographed in 2 books. It is a mid 1500s piece. In
the older book it is called 'Heian Jo Sukashi'. In
another book it is called 'Kyo Sukashi' and the age is
denoted in the subsequent description.
I suppose you could call it a "ko kyo" sukashi, but
sounds odd to me.

I would have thought Richard George's first tsuba
could be called "Heianjo Sukashi" or late Muromachi.


Curran



--- David Zincavage <jdz@...> wrote:

> I'm a bit puzzled about Heianjo sukashi tsubas. Why
> do you suppose it is that neither Torigoye nor
> Sasano discuss them? Heianjo, in this case, I would
> assume, just means they were made in Kyoto. So, how
> would Heianjo sukashi be different from Kyo
> sukashi? How does one identify these?
>
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been
> removed]
>
>

messages.subject: Heianjo Sukashi questions
messages.msgSnippet: I m a bit puzzled about Heianjo sukashi tsubas.  Why do you suppose it is that neither Torigoye nor Sasano discuss them?  Heianjo, in this case, I would
messages.messageBody:
I'm a bit puzzled about Heianjo sukashi tsubas. Why do you suppose it is that neither Torigoye nor Sasano discuss them? Heianjo, in this case, I would assume, just means they were made in Kyoto. So, how would Heianjo sukashi be different from Kyo sukashi? How does one identify these?



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
